So no wonder his mouth is going to speak of wisdom and his tongue is going to talk of judgment because God's Word, his law is in his heart. And it's in his heart because he loves it. Remember the point that we looked at that he had a plan to memorize God's Word. He said, oh, how love I thy law, but we find that as we study through Psalm 119, we see all of these evidences that are provided to us, scattered through this psalm, that help us to see how the psalmist, there's overwhelming evidence to support the claim that he loves God's Word. And this morning, I wonder in my life, I wonder in your life, I wonder if we were to take the time this morning to just evaluate our own lives and looking over just the last week or the last month or maybe just this calendar year, these two and a half months that we've had in 2023 and say, is there evidence in my life that would support the claim that I love God's Word, that I love God's Word? See, the evidence is overwhelming in support for what the psalmist declared, the expression of his love, but the evidence of his love. I'm gonna read to you an account of an individual, his name is William McPherson, and some of you may have heard of this individual at some point, but this man was a superintendent of a stone quarry, and as he was working there and he was successful in his work and what have you, he's working, obviously working in a stone quarry, there's some danger that's there, and he had, unfortunately, there was a blast that took place at this stone quarry, and he was in the wrong place, and he was severely injured. Through this blast and through this injury, this man lost his eyesight and both of his hands in the explosion. I want you to think about being in that position. No eyesight, no hands. I'm thankful that for folks that are blind, there's Braille. In fact, you can get Braille Bibles. They have those. And someone that's blind can still have the opportunity to, with a Braille Bible, read the Bible. In fact, some of you might know the name of Don Forrester. He was a pastor down in Fredericksburg at Faith Baptist Church for a number of years. And I remember the first time ever heard him preach was on a CD and I had no idea that he was blind. I'd never met the man before and somebody as soon as I got to Virginia gave me a CD of his because I was taking a trip to the Grand Canyon and said, hey, Brother Forster preached about his trip to the Grand Canyon, why don't you listen to this on the way? And I did and I had no idea that he was blind. And I'm hearing him talk about all these things and then I find out that he's blind and it was very interesting as somebody would have to detail things to him and explain things and so on and so forth. But then I heard him preach in person. Phenomenal. Has anyone ever, you've ever been in a setting where Don Forster preached? My dad, anyone else? He stands up there, he's completely blind and he has, and he just, he uses his hand right here and I mean, it's phenomenal. But this man lost both of his hands. No eyesight, no hands. But this man, William McPherson, was determined to read the Bible. He was determined to read the Bible. So here's what he did. He learned how to read raised letters with the tip of his tongue. He learned how to read raised letters with the tip of his tongue. It is said that William McPherson read through the Bible four times with the tip of his tongue. That's phenomenal. That's phenomenal. But that's the testimony of somebody that said, I love God's Word. And though I've lost my eyesight and though I've lost my hands, I want to read God's Word. Unfortunately, surveys have been taken for years now. Surveys, I'm not sure who they survey, but surveys have been taken for years of people that claim to be Christians. And again, I say claim to be because I don't know who they're surveying. They ask the question how often they read their Bibles. They ask the question of how many have read their Bible through once, not just in a year, but in their lifetime. And consistently those statistics are sad as to how few ever read the Bible from Genesis to Revelation. I'm not talking about, and again, I don't know the people, so I don't know if they're saved. They claim to be Christians. But here's a man that's lost his eyesight in both of his hands and it's said that four times with the tip of his tongue he read the Bible from cover to cover. And we can look at that and we say, that's amazing. That's just the evidence of an individual that loves God's Word. What would cause him to have that kind of love for God's Word? Well, he understood what it was. He understood that God's Word was God's Word. All Scripture is given by inspiration of God. He understood that it had been preserved. He understood that it was profitable. He understood all that we've looked at these past few weeks and he said, I need to read the Bible. And I'm not sure how I'm going to be able to read it, but I need to read it. And he learned to read letters with the tip of his tongue. Unbelievable. Amazing. But the evidence of a man that loved God's Word. This morning we've looked at ten things from Psalm 119 that I believe, and I think you could find more, but I believe they reveal to us, they provide for us evidence that supports the claim when the psalmist says, oh how love I thy law. It is my meditation all the day. Because we can make any claim we want, but is there evidence to support the claim? I believe this morning that the answer to that question for the psalmist would be yes. Absolutely there is evidence that supports the claim that the psalmist expressed when he said, I love God's Word. But what about our lives? What about my life? What about your life? Is the evidence there? Does the evidence support the claim? I love God's Word. I love God's Word. Those ten things, I'm not going to repeat them, but I do want you to evaluate your own life. Ask the Lord to help us this morning. Do I really love God's Word? Let's pray. Father we love you. We thank you for loving us. We thank you for the testimony of the psalmist and as we've noted last week how he expressed his love for thy Word. We looked at a number of reasons that led to his declaration as to why he would say, oh how love I thy law. But now this morning as we look at the evidence that supports the claim. God I pray that you would help each of us this morning to evaluate our own lives. That we would examine our own lives and we would be honest in our evaluation. That we would be humble in our evaluation. I say that I love God's Word. But is the evidence there to support the claim? We thank you for the testimony of Mr. McPherson. No doubt he loved thy Word. And God I pray that through your Word this morning you would cause us to have a greater appreciation for your Word, a greater love for your Word. That the evidence would be just so obvious in our lives that even others that would look at us and say man they must really love the Bible. They love God's Word. They're always talking about it. Lord I pray that you would help us this morning. Work in hearts and lives as only you can. We'll thank you for the work that you'll do for it's in Christ's name we pray.
